comments.body: I would suggest indicating how many there typically are of each, at least distinguish which only have one instance (e.g. node controller) vs. may have many instances (e.g. replication controller). For the latter category, explain how many there are (e.g. for replication controller I would rewrite as "For each ReplicationController object in the system, there is a replication controller that is responsible for maintaining the correct number of pods for a corresponding ReplicationController.")

> I would suggest indicating how many there typically are of each

No controller has more than one, though?

> For each ReplicationController object in the system, there is a replication controller that is responsible for maintaining the correct number of pods for a corresponding ReplicationController."

That's just not true, though; there's a single replication controller manager (replication controller controller?). We don't even start a thread per RC object. RC object is very unfortunately named for talking about the thing that actually implements it.
Yeah, never mind, I was confusing controllers and objects that are controlled.

I meant more like daemons started one per node via manifests passed to the kubelet via --config, to clarify why docker ps shows a fluentd pod when they didn't start one, and deleting them will lead to the kubelet starting another
I did reference that it looked for static config files. Feel free to send a PR expanding on that if you still want more detail :)
